Identification.LongTitle: An Act to amend the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999, to make related amendments to the Food and Drugs Act and to repeal the Perfluorooctane Sulfonate Virtual Elimination Act
Identification.ShortTitle: Strengthening Environmental Protection for a Healthier Canada Act
Identification.RunningHead: Strengthening Environmental Protection for a Healthier Canada Act

Provision.Text: This enactment amends the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 to, among other things,

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: recognize that every individual in Canada has a right to a healthy environment as provided under that Act;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: provide that the Government of Canada must protect that right as provided under that Act, and, in doing so, may balance that right with relevant factors;

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: require the development of an implementation framework that sets out how that right will be considered in the administration of that Act, and require that research, studies or monitoring activities be conducted to support the Government of Canada in protecting that right;

Provision.Label: (d)
Provision.Text: authorize the Minister of the Environment to add to the Domestic Substances List certain substances that were in commerce in Canada and subject to the Food and Drugs Act between January 1, 1987 and September 13, 2001, and provide that any substance may be deleted from the List when it is no longer in commerce in Canada;

Provision.Label: (e)
Provision.Text: require that the Minister of the Environment and the Minister of Health develop a plan that specifies the substances to which those Ministers are satisfied priority should be given in assessing whether they are toxic or capable of becoming toxic;

Provision.Label: (f)
Provision.Text: provide that any person may request that those Ministers assess a substance;

Provision.Label: (g)
Provision.Text: require the Minister of the Environment to compile a list of substances that that Minister and the Minister of Health have reason to suspect are capable of becoming toxic or that have been determined to be capable of becoming toxic;

Provision.Label: (h)
Provision.Text: require that, when those Ministers conduct or interpret the results of certain assessments — or conduct or interpret the results of a review of decisions of certain governments — in order to determine whether a substance is toxic or capable of becoming toxic, they consider available information on whether there is a vulnerable population in relation to the substance and on the cumulative effects that may result from exposure to the substance in combination with exposure to other substances;

Provision.Label: (i)
Provision.Text: provide that certain substances be classified as substances that pose the highest risk based on, among other things, their properties or characteristics;

Provision.Label: (j)
Provision.Text: require that those Ministers give priority to the total, partial or conditional prohibition of activities in relation to toxic substances that are specified in Part 1 of Schedule 1 of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999, or to the total, partial or conditional prohibition of releases of those substances into the environment, when regulations or instruments respecting preventive or control actions in relation to those substances are developed;

Provision.Label: (k)
Provision.Text: expand certain regulation-making, information-gathering and pollution prevention powers under that Act, including by adding a reference to products that may release substances into the environment;

Provision.Label: (l)
Provision.Text: allow the risks associated with certain toxic substances to be managed by preventive or control actions taken under any other Act of Parliament, and the obligations under sections 91 and 92 of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 to be the responsibility of whoever of the Minister of the Environment or the Minister of Health is best placed to fulfil them;

Provision.Label: (m)
Provision.Text: expand the powers of the Minister of the Environment to vary either the contents of a significant new activity notice with respect to a substance not on the Domestic Substances List or the contents of the List itself with respect to a substance on the List that is subject to the significant new activities provisions of that Act;

Provision.Label: (n)
Provision.Text: extend the requirement, to notify persons of the obligation to comply with the significant new activity provisions of that Act when a substance that is subject to those provisions is transferred to them, so that it applies with respect to substances on the Domestic Substances List, and authorize that Minister to limit by class the persons who are required to be notified of the obligation when a substance that is subject to those provisions is transferred to them; and

Provision.Label: (o)
Provision.Text: require that confidentiality requests made under section 313 of the Act be accompanied by reasons, and to allow the Minister of the Environment to disclose the explicit chemical or biological name of a substance or the explicit biological name of a living organism in certain circumstances.

The enactment also makes related amendments to the Food and Drugs Act to enable the assessment and management of risks to the environment associated with foods, drugs, cosmetics and devices by, among other things,

Provision.Label: (a)
Provision.Text: prohibiting persons from conducting certain activities in respect of a drug unless the Minister of Health has conducted an assessment of the risks to the environment presented by certain substances contained in that drug;

Provision.Label: (b)
Provision.Text: enabling the Minister of Health to take measures in respect of the risks to the environment that a drug may present throughout its life cycle; and

Provision.Label: (c)
Provision.Text: providing the Governor in Council with supporting regulation-making authorities.
Finally, the enactment repeals the Perfluorooctane Sulfonate Virtual Elimination Act.

Provision.Text: His Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate and House of Commons of Canada, enacts as follows:

Section.Text: This Act may be cited as the Strengthening Environmental Protection for a Healthier Canada Act.

Subsection.Text: The preamble to the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 is amended by adding the following after the first paragraph:

Provision.Text: Whereas the Government of Canada recognizes that every individual in Canada has a right to a healthy environment as provided under this Act;

Subsection.Text: The third paragraph of the preamble to the Act is replaced by the following:

Provision.Text: Whereas the Government of Canada acknowledges the need to control and manage pollutants and wastes if their release into the environment cannot be prevented;

Subsection.Text: The sixth paragraph of the preamble to the French version of the Act is replaced by the following:

Text.Language: qu’il s’engage à adopter le principe de précaution, si bien qu’en cas de risques de dommages graves ou irréversibles, l’absence de certitude scientifique absolue ne doit pas servir de prétexte pour remettre à plus tard l’adoption de mesures effectives visant à prévenir la dégradation de l’environnement;

Subsection.Text: The preamble to the Act is amended by adding the following after the eighth paragraph:

Provision.Text: Whereas the Government of Canada is committed to implementing the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, including free, prior and informed consent;

Subsection.Text: The preamble to the Act is amended by adding the following after the ninth paragraph:

Provision.Text: Whereas the Government of Canada recognizes the importance of considering vulnerable populations in assessing whether substances are toxic or capable of becoming toxic;
Whereas the Government of Canada recognizes the importance of minimizing the risks posed by exposure to toxic substances and the cumulative effects of toxic substances;

Subsection.Text: The preamble to the Act is amended by adding the following after the 10th paragraph:

Provision.Text: Whereas the Government of Canada recognizes the role of science and Indigenous knowledge in the process of making decisions related to the protection of the environment and human health, as well as the importance of promoting the development and timely incorporation of scientifically justified alternative methods and strategies in the testing and assessment of substances to replace, reduce or refine the use of vertebrate animals;

Subsection.Text: The 13th paragraph of the preamble to the Act is replaced by the following:

Provision.Text: Whereas the Government of Canada will endeavour to remove threats to biological diversity through pollution prevention as well as the control and management of the risk of any adverse effects of the use and release of toxic substances, pollutants and wastes;

Whereas the Government of Canada recognizes the importance of encouraging the progressive substitution of substances, processes and technologies with alternatives that are safer for the environment or human health, when they are economically and technically viable;
Whereas the Government of Canada is committed to openness, transparency and accountability in respect of the protection of the environment and human health;

Whereas the Government of Canada recognizes the importance of Canadians having information, including by means of the packaging and labelling of products, regarding the risks posed by toxic substances to the environment or to human health;
Whereas the Government of Canada is committed to implementing a risk-based approach to the assessment and management of chemical substances;

Subsection.Text: Paragraph 2(1)(a) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: exercise its powers in a manner that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: protects the environment and human health, including the health of vulnerable populations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: applies the precautionary principle, which provides that the lack of full scientific certainty shall not be used as a reason for postponing cost-effective measures to prevent environmental degradation if there are threats of serious or irreversible damage, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: promotes and reinforces enforceable pollution prevention approaches;

Subsection.Text: Subsection 2(1) of the Act is amended by adding the following after paragraph (a.1):

Paragraph.Label: (a.2)
Paragraph.Text: protect the right of every individual in Canada to a healthy environment as provided under this Act, subject to any reasonable limits;

Paragraph.Label: (a.3)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to paragraph (a.2), uphold principles such as principles of environmental justice — including the avoidance of adverse effects that disproportionately affect vulnerable populations — the principle of non-regression and the principle of intergenerational equity;

Subsection.Text: Subsection 2(1) of the Act is amended by adding the following after paragraph (k):

Paragraph.Label: (k.1)
Paragraph.Text: encourage the development and timely incorporation of scientifically justified alternative methods and strategies in the testing and assessment of substances to replace, reduce or refine the use of vertebrate animals;

Subsection.Text: The portion of the definition substance in subsection 3(1) of the Act after paragraph (d) and before paragraph (e) is replaced by the following:

ContinuedDefinition.Text: and, except for the purposes of sections 66 to 66.2, 80 to 89 and 104 to 115, includes

Subsection.Text: Subsection 3(1) of the Act is amended by adding the following in alphabetical order:

Definition.Text: healthy environment means an environment that is clean, healthy and sustainable. (environnement sain)

precautionary principle means Principle 15 of the 1992 Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, which provides that the lack of full scientific certainty shall not be used as a reason for postponing cost-effective measures to prevent environmental degradation if there are threats of serious or irreversible damage. (principe de précaution)

vulnerable population means a group of individuals within the Canadian population who, due to greater susceptibility or greater exposure, may be at an increased risk of experiencing adverse health effects from exposure to substances. (population vulnérable)

Section.Text: The Act is amended by adding the following after the heading of Part 1:

Heading.TitleText: Implementation of Right to a Healthy Environment

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph 2(1)(a.2), the Ministers shall, within two years after the day on which this section comes into force, develop an implementation framework to set out how the right to a healthy environment will be considered in the administration of this Act.
Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), the implementation framework shall set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the process under subsection 76.1(1) in respect of the protection of the right to a healthy environment.

Subsection.Text: The implementation framework, in a manner consistent with the purposes of this Act, shall, among other things, elaborate on

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the principles to be considered in the administration of this Act, such as principles of environmental justice — including the avoidance of adverse effects that disproportionately affect vulnerable populations — the principle of non-regression and the principle of intergenerational equity, according to which it is important to meet the needs of the present generation without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: research, studies or monitoring activities to support the protection of the right to a healthy environment referred to in paragraph 2(1)(a.2);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the relevant factors to be taken into account in interpreting and applying that right and in determining the reasonable limits to which it is subject, including social, health, scientific and economic factors; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: mechanisms to support the protection of that right.

Subsection.Text: In developing the implementation framework, the Ministers shall consult any interested persons.
The Minister shall publish the implementation framework in the manner that the Minister considers appropriate.
The Minister shall include in the annual report required by section 342 a report on the implementation of the framework.
The portion of subsection 13(1) of the Act before paragraph (a) is replaced by the following:

The Environmental Registry shall contain notices and other documents published or made publicly available by the Ministers or either Minister under this Act, and shall also include, subject to the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act,
Subsection 13(2) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Subsection.MarginalNote: Form and manner of Environmental Registry
Subsection.Text: The Minister may determine the form of the Environmental Registry and how it is to be kept, so long as the registry is publicly accessible and searchable and is in electronic form.

Section.Text: Section 15 of the Act is replaced by the following:

The rights conferred by this Part are in addition to the right to request, under section 76, that a substance be assessed, the right to file a notice of objection under Parts 1, 7 and 11 and the right to request under Parts 7 and 11 that a board of review be established under section 333.
Section 44 of the Act is amended by adding the following after subsection (3):

Subsection.MarginalNote: Protection of right to healthy environment
Subsection.Text: The Ministers shall conduct research, studies or monitoring activities to support the Government of Canada in protecting the right to a healthy environment referred to in paragraph 2(1)(a.2).
Paragraph 45(a) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conduct research and studies, including biomonitoring surveys, relating to the role of substances in illnesses or in health problems;

Subsection.Text: Section 45 of the Act is renumbered as subsection 45(1) and is amended by adding the following:
For greater certainty, the research and studies referred to in paragraph (1)(a) may relate to vulnerable populations.
Paragraph 46(1)(a) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: substances specified in the plan developed under section 73;

Subsection.Text: Subsection 46(1) of the Act is amended by adding the following after paragraph (e):

Paragraph.Label: (e.1)
Paragraph.Text: products that contain a substance that is toxic under section 64 or that may become toxic, or products that may release such a substance into the environment;

Subsection.Text: Subsection 46(1) of the Act is amended by adding the following after paragraph (k):

Paragraph.Label: (k.1)
Paragraph.Text: activities that may contribute to pollution;

Paragraph.Label: (k.2)
Paragraph.Text: hydraulic fracturing;

Paragraph.Label: (k.3)
Paragraph.Text: tailings ponds;

Subsection.Text: Subsection 56(1) of the Act is replaced by the following:

The Minister may, at any time, publish in the Canada Gazette and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate a notice requiring any person or class of persons described in the notice to prepare and implement a pollution prevention plan in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a substance or group of substances specified on the list of toxic substances in Schedule 1;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a substance or group of substances with respect to which subsection 166(1) or 176(1) applies; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a product that contains a substance specified on the list of toxic substances in Schedule 1 or that may release such a substance into the environment.

Subsection.Text: The notice may include a requirement that the plan prioritize the identification, development or use of safer or more sustainable alternatives to the substance, group of substances or product.
Paragraph 56(2)(a) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the substance, group of substances or product in relation to which the plan is to be prepared;

Subsection.Text: Subsection 56(4) of the Act is replaced by the following:

The Minister shall publish in the Environmental Registry and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate a notice stating the name of any person for whom an extension is granted, whether the extension is for the preparation or the implementation of the plan, and the duration of the period of the extension.
Section 56 of the Act is amended by adding the following after subsection (5):

A notice under subsection (1) may include a requirement that the person to whom the notice is directed file with the Minister, within the periods specified in the notice, written reports on their progress in implementing the plan.

Section.Text: Subsection 60(1) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Subsection.Text: The Minister may publish in the Canada Gazette and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate a notice requiring any person or class of persons described in the notice who are required to prepare and implement a pollution prevention plan under section 56 to submit, within the period specified by the Minister, the plan or any part of the plan for the purpose of determining and assessing preventive or control actions in respect of a substance, group of substances or product.

Section.Text: Sections 65 and 65.1 of the Act are repealed.

Subsection.Text: The portion of subsection 66(1) of the Act before paragraph (a) is replaced by the following:

The Minister shall, for the purpose of section 81, maintain a list to be known as the Domestic Substances List and, subject to subsection 66.2(1), the List shall specify all substances that the Minister is satisfied were, between January 1, 1984 and December 31, 1986,
Paragraph 66(2)(a) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the substances referred to in subsection (1), unless the substance has been deleted from the Domestic Substances List under subsection 66.2(1); and

Section.Text: The Act is amended by adding the following after section 66:

Section.MarginalNote: Domestic Substances List — Food and Drugs Act

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, for the purpose of section 81, add a substance to the Domestic Substances List if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the substance was included on the version of the Revised In Commerce List that was prepared by the Minister of Health after the end, on November 3, 2019, of acceptance of substance nominations to that List and that is referred to in the Canada Gazette, Part I, Volume 152, Number 44, as the static list;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the substance is not referred to in Annex I to the notice entitled “Removal of substances with no commercial activity from the Revised In Commerce List” published in the Canada Gazette, Part I, Volume 156, Number 8; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: no conditions specified under paragraph 84(1)(a) in respect of the substance are in effect.

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: If the substance appears on the Non-domestic Substances List, the Minister shall delete it from that List.

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, by order, designate any person or class of persons to exercise the powers set out in subsection (1).

If the Minister is satisfied that a substance referred to in subsection 66(1) that is specified on the Domestic Substances List — or a substance added to the List under subsection 66.1(1) or 87(1) or (5) — is not being manufactured in Canada, imported into Canada, in Canadian commerce or used for commercial manufacturing purposes in Canada, the Minister may delete the substance from the List and may add it to the Non-domestic Substances List.

Before deleting a substance from the Domestic Substances List under subsection (1), the Minister shall publish in the Canada Gazette and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate a notice indicating the Minister’s intention to delete it from the List.
Within 60 days after the publication of the notice, any person may file written comments with the Minister.
The Minister may, by order, designate any person or class of persons to exercise the powers and perform the duties and functions set out in this section.
Paragraph 67(1)(a) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: respecting a property or characteristic of a substance, including persistence, bioaccumulation, carcinogenicity, mutagenicity and reproductive toxicity;

Subsection.Text: Subsection 67(1) of the Act is amended by striking out “and” at the end of paragraph (c) and by replacing paragraph (d) with the following:

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the conditions, test procedures and laboratory practices to be followed for analysing, testing or measuring the property or characteristic, including conditions, test procedures and laboratory practices to be followed for replacing, reducing or refining the use of vertebrate animals; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: respecting, for the purpose of subsection 77(3), the classification of a substance as a substance that poses the highest risk.

Subsection.Text: The portion of section 68 of the Act before subparagraph (a)(i) is replaced by the following:

Section.Text: For the purpose of assessing whether a substance is toxic or is capable of becoming toxic — or for the purpose of assessing whether to control, or the manner in which to control, a substance, a product that contains a substance or a product that may release a substance into the environment — including a substance specified on the list of toxic substances in Schedule 1, either Minister may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: collect or generate data and conduct investigations respecting any matter in relation to the substance or product including

Subsection.Text: Paragraph 68(a) of the Act is amended by adding the following after subparagraph (iii):

Subparagraph.Label: (iii.1)
Subparagraph.Text: whether exposure to the substance in combination with exposure to other substances has the potential to cause cumulative effects,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii.2)
Subparagraph.Text: whether there is a vulnerable population or environment in relation to the substance,

Subsection.Text: Subparagraphs 68(a)(v) and (vi) of the Act are replaced by the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the ability of the substance to cause delayed or latent effects over the lifetime of an organism, including carcinogenic, mutagenic or neurotoxic effects,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the ability of the substance to cause survival impairment of an organism,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi.1)
Subparagraph.Text: the ability of the substance to disrupt the reproductive system or endocrine system of an organism,

Subsection.Text: Subparagraph 68(a)(xii) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (xii)
Subparagraph.Text: the existence, development and use of safer or more sustainable alternatives to the substance or product,

Subsection.Text: Paragraph 68(a) of the Act is amended by striking out “and” at the end of subparagraph (xiii), by adding “and” at the end of subparagraph (xiv) and by adding the following after subparagraph (xiv):

Subparagraph.Label: (xv)
Subparagraph.Text: the manner in which the public may be provided with information regarding the substance or product, including, in the case of a product, by labelling it;

Subsection.Text: Paragraph 68(c) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide information and make recommendations respecting any matter in relation to the substance or product, including measures to control the presence of the substance or product in the environment.

Section.Text: The Act is amended by adding the following after section 68:

Subsection.Text: The Ministers shall, to the extent practicable, use scientifically justified alternative methods and strategies to replace, reduce or refine the use of vertebrate animals in the generation of data and the conduct of investigations under paragraph 68(a).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Methods and strategies to refine use
Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), methods and strategies to refine the use of vertebrate animals include minimizing pain and distress caused to vertebrate animals used in the generation of data and the conduct of investigations under paragraph 68(a).
Subsection 69(2.1) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Nothing in subsection (2) shall prevent either Minister or both Ministers from exercising the powers under subsection (1) at any time after the 60th day following the day on which an offer is made under subsection (2).
Subsection 69(3) of the English version of the Act is replaced by the following:

Guidelines issued under this section shall be made available to the public, and the Minister who issued the guidelines shall give notice of them in the Canada Gazette and in any other manner that that Minister considers appropriate.
The portion of subsection 71(1) of the Act before paragraph (b) is replaced by the following:

Section.MarginalNote: Notice requiring information, samples or testing

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, for the purpose of assessing whether a substance is toxic or is capable of becoming toxic — or for the purpose of assessing whether to control, or the manner in which to control, a substance, a product that contains a substance or a product that may release a substance into the environment — including a substance specified on the list of toxic substances in Schedule 1,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: publish in the Canada Gazette and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate a notice requiring any person who is described in the notice and who is or was within the period specified in the notice engaged in any activity involving the substance or product, as the case may be, to notify the Minister that the person is or was during that period engaged in that activity;

Subsection.Text: Paragraph 71(1)(c) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to section 72, send a written notice to any person who is described in the notice and who is or was within the period specified in the notice engaged in any activity involving the importation or manufacturing of the substance or product, as the case may be, requiring the person to conduct toxicological or other tests that the Minister may specify in the notice and submit the results of the tests to the Minister.

Subsection.Text: The portion of subsection 71(2) of the English version of the Act before paragraph (a) is replaced by the following:
A notice published under paragraph (1)(b) may require any information and samples, including
Paragraph 71(2)(a) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a substance, available toxicological information, available monitoring information, samples of the substance and information on the quantities, composition, uses and distribution of the substance;

Paragraph.Label: (a.1)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a product that contains a substance or that may release a substance into the environment, information on the quantities, composition, manufacturing, processing, packaging, labelling, uses and distribution of the product;

Subsection.Text: Subsection 71(2) of the Act is amended by adding “and” at the end of paragraph (b) and by adding the following after that paragraph:

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: information on the method used to quantify any information that is provided.

Subsection.Text: Section 71 of the Act is amended by adding the following after subsection (2):

Subsection.MarginalNote: Method and manner — notice under paragraph (1)(b)
Subsection.Text: A notice published under paragraph (1)(b) may specify the method to be used to quantify any information that is to be provided and the manner in which that information and any sample is to be provided.
A notice sent under paragraph (1)(c) may, among other things, require the person to provide any information and samples, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a substance or of a product that contains a substance or that may release a substance into the environment, toxicological information, monitoring information, test samples and information on the quantities, composition, uses and distribution of the substance or product; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information on the methods, test procedures and laboratory practices followed for performing any required test and on the conditions under which those tests are conducted.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Method and manner — notice under paragraph (1)(c)
Subsection.Text: The notice sent under paragraph (1)(c) may, among other things, specify

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions, methods, test procedures and laboratory practices to be followed for conducting sampling, analyses, measurements, quantification or monitoring as part of any required test;

Paragraph.Label: (a.1)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions, methods, test procedures and laboratory practices to be followed to replace, reduce or refine the use of vertebrate animals;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which the test results are to be submitted;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the method to be used to quantify any information that is to be provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)

Subsection.Text: Subsection 71(4) of the English version of the Act is replaced by the following:

Section.Text: Sections 72 to 74 of the Act are replaced by the following:

The Minister may not exercise the power under paragraph 71(1)(c) in relation to a substance, a product that contains a substance or a product that may release a substance into the environment unless the Ministers have reason to suspect that the substance is toxic or capable of becoming toxic or it has been determined under this Act that the substance is toxic or capable of becoming toxic.

Subsection.Text: The Ministers shall, within two years after the day on which this section receives royal assent, develop and publish a plan with timelines

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that specifies the substances to which the Ministers are satisfied priority should be given in assessing whether they are toxic or capable of becoming toxic;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that specifies the activities or initiatives in relation to assessing, controlling or otherwise managing the risks to the environment or to human health posed by substances that are or will be undertaken under an Act of Parliament for whose administration either Minister is responsible and which the Ministers are of the opinion should be prioritized; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: that specifies activities or initiatives to promote the development and timely incorporation of scientifically justified alternative methods and strategies in the testing and assessment of substances to replace, reduce or refine the use of vertebrate animals.

Subsection.Text: In developing a proposed plan, and in implementing the plan, the Ministers

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: may consult with the Committee, a government department or agency, aboriginal people, representatives of industry and labour and municipal authorities or with persons interested in the quality of the environment or the preservation and improvement of public health;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall consider whether assessing substances by class is more advantageous than assessing them individually, with a view toward avoiding substitutions within the class that may be harmful; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall take into account the matters referred to in paragraph 68(a), including the manner in which the public may be provided with information regarding substances or products including, in the case of products, by labelling them.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall publish the proposed plan in the Environmental Registry and shall give notice in the Canada Gazette and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate of the proposed plan’s availability.
Within 60 days after the publication of the notice, any person may file with the Minister written comments on the proposed plan.
The Ministers shall take into account the comments and may amend the proposed plan in any manner they consider appropriate based on those comments.
The Minister shall publish the plan in the Canada Gazette and in any other manner that the Minister considers appropriate.
The Ministers shall review the plan within eight years after it is published and every eight years after that.
If after reviewing the plan the Ministers propose to amend it, subsections (2) to (7) apply to the proposed amended plan.

Section.Text: The Ministers shall include in the annual report required by section 342 a report on the progress made in assessing the substances specified in the plan developed under section 73 and in respect of any activities or initiatives specified in the plan.

Section.MarginalNote: Notification of persons required to comply

Subsection.Text: Section 209 of the Act is amended by adding the following after subsection (4):

Regulations made under this section may authorize the Minister, in the circumstances and subject to the conditions and limits that may be specified in the regulations, to issue, amend, suspend and revoke permits and other authorizations in relation to any matter that is the subject of the regulations and to set their terms and conditions.
A permit or other authorization issued under regulations made under this section is not a statutory instrument as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Statutory Instruments Act.

Paragraph.Label: (a)

Subsection.Text: Paragraph 272(1)(b) of the Act is replaced by the following:

Subsection.Text: Subsection 313(1) of the French version of the Act is replaced by the following:

Text.Language: Quiconque fournit des renseignements au ministre sous le régime de la présente loi, ou à la commission de révision relativement à un avis d’opposition déposé aux termes de la présente loi, peut en même temps demander que les renseignements fournis soient considérés comme confidentiels.

Subsection.Text: Subsection 313(2) of the Act is replaced by the following:

A request for confidentiality shall be submitted, with reasons taking into account the criteria set out in paragraphs 20(1)(a) to (d) of the Access to Information Act, in writing and contain any supplementary information that may be prescribed.

The Minister shall review a statistically valid representative sample of requests granted under subsection (1) and determine whether, in respect of each of those requests, the person who made the request demonstrated that it concerned any of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: trade secrets of any person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: financial, commercial, scientific or technical information that is confidential information and that is treated consistently in a confidential manner by any person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: information the disclosure of which could reasonably be expected to result in material financial loss or gain to, or could reasonably be expected to prejudice the competitive position of, any person; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: information the disclosure of which could reasonably be expected to interfere with contractual or other negotiations of any person.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Requests deemed not to have been made
Subsection.Text: If the Minister determines that the person who made the request did not demonstrate that the request, in whole or in part, concerned information described in any of paragraphs (3)(a) to (d), then, for the purpose of any part of the request that does not concern such information, the request is deemed not to have been made.

The Minister shall include in the annual report required under section 342 the number of requests made under subsection (1), the number of requests reviewed, the number of requests that, in whole or in part, were deemed not to have been made and a summary of the information disclosed under sections 315 to 317.2.
The Minister may, by order, designate any person or class of persons to exercise the powers and perform the duties and functions set out in this section.

Section.Text: Section 314 of the Act is replaced by the following:
The Minister shall not disclose any information in respect of which a request for confidentiality has been made under section 313, except in accordance with any of sections 315 to 317.2.

Subsection.Text: The portion of paragraph 316(1)(c) of the Act before subparagraph (i) is replaced by the following:

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: under an agreement or arrangement between the Government of Canada or any of its institutions and any other government in Canada, the government of a foreign state or an international organization or any of its institutions, or between the Minister and any other minister of the Crown in right of Canada or a board or agency of the Government of Canada, if

Subsection.Text: Subparagraph 316(1)(c)(ii) of the Act of the Act is replaced by the following:

Section.Text: The Act is amended by adding the following after section 317:

Subsection.Text: The Minister may disclose the explicit chemical or biological name of a substance in respect of which a request for confidentiality has been made if the Minister takes or has taken any of the following measures:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to permit, under paragraph 84(1)(a), the manufacture or importation of the substance, subject to any conditions that are specified;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to prohibit the manufacture or importation of the substance under paragraph 84(1)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to publish, in respect of the substance, a notice under subsection 85(1) or (4); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to amend the Domestic Substances List in respect of the substance under subsection 87(3) or (4.1).

Subsection.Text: The Minister may disclose the explicit biological name of a living organism in respect of which a request for confidentiality has been made if the Minister takes or has taken any of the following measures:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to permit, under paragraph 109(1)(a), the manufacture or importation of the living organism, subject to any conditions that are specified;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to prohibit the manufacture or importation of the living organism under paragraph 109(1)(b);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: to publish, in respect of the living organism, a notice under subsection 110(1) or (4); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to amend the Domestic Substances List in respect of the living organism under subsection 112(3) or (5).

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall disclose the explicit chemical or biological name of a substance or the explicit biological name of a living organism in respect of which a request for confidentiality has been made if the Ministers recommend or have recommended to the Governor in Council the addition of the substance or the living organism to Part 1 or 2 of the list of toxic substances in Schedule 1 under subsection 90(1).

The Minister may disclose the explicit chemical or biological name of a substance or the explicit biological name of a living organism after the expiry of a period of 10 years after the day on which a request for confidentiality under section 313 is made.

The Minister shall publish a notice in the Canada Gazette of the Minister’s intention to disclose the explicit chemical or biological name under subsection (1) at least 60 days before the proposed disclosure.
Within 60 days after the publication of the notice, the person who made the request for confidentiality or the person’s successor or assign may file with the Minister comments respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: whether the public interest in the disclosure of the name clearly outweighs in importance

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any material financial loss or prejudice to the competitive position of the person or the person’s successor or assign, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any damage to the privacy, reputation or human dignity of any person that may result from the disclosure of that name; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether the disclosure is prohibited under section 20 of the Access to Information Act.

Subsection.Text: At least 24 hours before disclosing the name under subsection (1), the Minister shall give notice of the proposed disclosure to the person who made the request for confidentiality or the person’s successor or assign. The notice is not required if the person to whom it is to be given cannot be found after reasonable efforts have been made to do so.
If an emergency exists, subsections (2) and (3) do not apply and the notice of disclosure required in subsection (4) may be given later than the time provided for in that subsection.

Section.Text: The Minister shall include in the annual report required by section 342 a report respecting the explicit chemical or biological names of substances and the explicit biological names of living organisms disclosed under section 317.1 or 317.2.
Subsections 330(3) and (3.1) of the Act are repealed.
Subsections 332(1) and (2) of the Act are replaced by the following:

Section.MarginalNote: Publication of proposed orders and regulations

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall publish in the Canada Gazette a copy of every order or regulation proposed to be made by the Minister or the Governor in Council under this Act, except a list, or an amendment to a list, referred to in any of sections 66 to 66.2, 87, 105 to 105.2 and 112 or an interim order made under section 94, 163, 173, 183 or 200.1.

Any person may file with the Minister comments, or a notice of objection requesting that a board of review be established under section 333 and stating the reasons for the objection, within 60 days after the publication of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a proposed order or regulation referred to in subsection (1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a proposed instrument respecting preventive or control actions in relation to a substance that is required by section 91 to be published in the Canada Gazette; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement referred to in subparagraph 91(1)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii).

Subsection.Text: Subsection 333(1) of the Act is replaced by the following:

If a person files a notice of objection under subsection 332(2) in respect of a decision or a proposed order, regulation or instrument made by the Governor in Council, a decision or a proposed order or instrument made by either or both Ministers or a statement referred to in subparagraph 91(1)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii), the Minister or the Ministers may establish a board of review to inquire into the nature and extent of the danger posed by the substance in respect of which the decision or statement is made or the order, regulation or instrument is proposed.
Subsection 333(6) of the Act is repealed.

Section.Text: The Act is amended by adding the following after section 342:
The Minister shall include in the annual report required by section 342 information related to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: consultations with aboriginal peoples and aboriginal governments, including a summary of the key issues raised, in relation to matters under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the administration of this Act in respect of aboriginal peoples and aboriginal governments, including the measures taken to advance reconciliation as reflected in section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982 and in the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act; and

Section.Text: Schedule 1 to the Act is replaced by the Schedule 1 set out in the schedule to this Act.
Unless the context otherwise requires, words and expressions used in sections 60 to 62 have the same meaning as in the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999.

Section.MarginalNote: Statement under subsection 77(1) — deemed recommendation to add to Part 1

Subsection.Text: If, before the day on which subsection 21(1) of this Act comes into force, a statement is published under subsection 77(1) of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 indicating that the measure that the Ministers propose to take in respect of a substance is a recommendation to add the substance to the List of Toxic Substances in Schedule 1 of that Act and to implement virtual elimination under subsection 65(3) of that Act and no statement confirming or amending that measure has been published under paragraph 77(6)(b) of that Act before that day, the measure is deemed to be a recommendation, made under paragraph 77(2)(c) of that Act, as that paragraph reads after that day, to add the substance on the list of toxic substances in Part 1 of Schedule 1, as that Schedule reads after that day.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Statement under subsection 77(1) — deemed recommendation to add to Part 2
Subsection.Text: If, before the day on which subsection 21(1) of this Act comes into force, a statement is published under subsection 77(1) of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 indicating that the measure that the Ministers propose to take in respect of the substance is a recommendation to add the substance to the List of Toxic Substances in Schedule 1 of that Act without implementing virtual elimination under subsection 65(3) of that Act and no statement confirming or amending that measure is published under paragraph 77(6)(b) of that Act before that day, the measure is deemed to be a recommendation, made under paragraph 77(2)(d) of that Act, as enacted by that subsection 21(1), to add the substance on the list of toxic substances in Part 2 of Schedule 1, as that Schedule reads after that day.

Section.MarginalNote: Statement under paragraph 77(6)(b) — deemed recommendation to add to Part 1

Subsection.Text: If, before the day on which subsection 21(2) of this Act comes into force, a statement is published under paragraph 77(6)(b) of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 indicating that the measure that the Ministers propose to take, as confirmed or amended, in respect of a substance is a recommendation to add the substance to the List of Toxic Substances in Schedule 1 of that Act and to implement virtual elimination under subsection 65(3) of that Act, the statement is deemed to be a statement, published under paragraph 77(6)(b) of that Act, as it reads after that day, indicating that the measure, as confirmed or amended, is a recommendation to add the substance on the list of toxic substances in Part 1 of Schedule 1, as that Schedule reads after that day.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Statement under paragraph 77(6)(b) — deemed recommendation to add to Part 2
Subsection.Text: If, before the day on which subsection 21(2) of this Act comes into force, a statement is published under paragraph 77(6)(b) of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 indicating that the measure that the Ministers propose to take, as confirmed or amended, in respect of the substance is a recommendation to add the substance to the List of Toxic Substances in Schedule 1 of that Act without the implementation of virtual elimination under subsection 65(3) of that Act, the statement is deemed to be a statement, published under paragraph 77(6)(b) of that Act, as it reads after that day, indicating that the measure, as confirmed or amended, is a recommendation to add the substance on the list of toxic substances in Part 2 of Schedule 1, as that Schedule reads after that day.

If a substance is added to the List of Toxic Substances in Schedule 1 of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 before the day on which section 58 of this Act comes into force but the substance is not specified on the list of toxic substances in Part 1 or 2 of Schedule 1 of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 on that day, the Governor in Council must as soon as feasible after that day make an order adding the substance

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to the list of toxic substances in Part 1 of Schedule 1 of that Act, if the Governor in Council is satisfied that the substance is toxic within the meaning of section 64 of that Act and if the Ministers recommended the implementation of virtual elimination under subsection 65(3) of that Act in relation to the substance; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to the list of toxic substances in Part 2 of Schedule 1 of that Act, if the Governor in Council is satisfied that the substance is toxic within the meaning of section 64 of that Act and if the Ministers did not recommend the implementation of virtual elimination under subsection 65(3) of that Act in relation to the substance.

Subsection.Text: If a substance is deleted from the List of Toxic Substances in Schedule 1 of the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, 1999 before the day on which section 58 of this Act comes into force but the substance is specified on the list of toxic substances in Part 1 or 2 of Schedule 1 of that Act as it reads after that day, the Governor in Council must as soon as feasible after that day make an order deleting the substance from the list of toxic substances on which it is specified.

Section.Text: The Minister of the Environment and the Minister of Health may, by regulation,

Paragraph.Label: (b)

Heading.TitleText: Related Amendments to the Food and Drugs Act

Section.Text: The Food and Drugs Act is amended by adding the following after section 11:

It is prohibited for a person to sell, or to manufacture, prepare, preserve, package or store for sale, any drug that contains a prescribed substance, unless the Minister has conducted an assessment, in accordance with the regulations made under paragraph 30(1)(l.1), of the risk to the environment presented by the substance.
The Act is amended by adding the following after section 21.3:

Subsection.Text: If the Minister believes that a therapeutic product may present a serious risk to the environment, the Minister may order a person to provide the Minister with information that is in the person’s control and that the Minister believes is necessary to determine whether the product presents such a risk.

The Minister may disclose confidential business information about a therapeutic product without notifying the person to whose business or affairs the information relates or obtaining their consent, if the Minister believes that the product may present a serious risk to the environment.

The Minister may disclose confidential business information about a therapeutic product without notifying the person to whose business or affairs the information relates or obtaining their consent, if the purpose of the disclosure is related to the protection of the environment and the disclosure is to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a government;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person from whom the Minister seeks advice; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person who carries out functions relating to the protection of the environment, including the assessment and management of risks to the environment.

Subsection.Text: In this section, government has the same meaning as in subsection 21.1(4).

Section.MarginalNote: Labelling or packaging — serious risk to environment
Section.Text: The Minister may, if he or she believes that doing so is necessary to prevent a serious risk to the environment, order the holder of a therapeutic product authorization that authorizes the import or sale of a therapeutic product to modify the product’s label or to modify or replace its package.

Section.MarginalNote: Minister’s powers — serious risk to environment

Subsection.Text: If the Minister believes that a therapeutic product presents a serious or imminent risk to the environment, he or she may order a person who sells the product to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: recall the product; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: send the product, or cause it to be sent, to a place specified in the order.

Subsection.Text: Subsections 21.3(2) to (6) apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, in respect of any order made under subsection (1).

Section.Text: Section 21.4 of the Act is replaced by the following:

Section.MarginalNote: Power — information relating to environmental effects
Section.Text: Subject to the regulations, the Minister may, for the purpose of obtaining additional information about a therapeutic product’s effects on the environment, order the holder of a therapeutic product authorization to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: compile information or conduct tests, studies or monitoring in respect of the therapeutic product; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide the Minister with the information or the results of the tests, studies or monitoring.

Subsection.Text: For greater certainty, orders made under any of sections 21.1 to 21.33 are not statutory instruments within the meaning of the Statutory Instruments Act.
The Minister shall ensure that any order made under any of sections 21.1 to 21.33 is publicly available.

Before recommending to the Governor in Council that a regulation be made under paragraph (1)(a.02), the Minister must take into account the degree of uncertainty respecting the risks to the environment associated with the use of a substance as an ingredient in a drug, including its release into the environment.
